datafield.subfield: Systematic errors in digital volume correlation due to the self-heating effect of a laboratory x-ray CT scanner

The use of digital volume correlation (DVC) in combination with a laboratory x-ray computed tomography (CT) for full-field internal 3D deformation measurement of opaque materials has flourished in recent years. During x-ray tomographic imaging, the heat generated by the x-ray tube changes the imaging geometry of x-ray scanner, and further introduces noticeable errors in DVC measurements. In this work, to provide practical guidance high-accuracy DVC measurement, the errors in displacements and strains measured by DVC due to the self-heating for effect of a commercially available x-ray scanner were experimentally investigated. The errors were characterized by performing simple rescan tests with different scan durations. The results indicate that the maximum strain errors associated with the self-heating of the x-ray scanner exceed 400 µε. Possible approaches for minimizing or correcting these displacement and strain errors are discussed. Finally, a series of translation and uniaxial compression tests were performed, in which strain errors were detected and then removed using pre-established artificial dilatational strain-time curve. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy and accuracy of the proposed strain error correction approach.

Full preheating of the x-ray scanner before image acquisition. This technique requires identifying the operation time of the x-ray tube required to reach thermal equilibrium. Then, each test performed thereafter would not have any variation in the self-heating error. However, this approach requires that the x-ray tube should be fully preheated for several hours (3 h for the scanner used herein) before scanning, which wastes the service time of the x-ray scanner

Strain error correction using pre-established artificial strain-time curve. In using this approach, the strain errors induced by the self-heating of the x-ray tube must be experimentally characterized as a function of operation time using repeated scans with the same scan parameters in advance. Then the measured strains can be corrected by subtracting artificial strains according to the recording time of the volume images

Reference sample compensation approach [, 32: #mstaa60adbib032]. This technique uses a fixed reference object, which is placed close to or adhered onto the test specimen but without any mechanical and thermal deformation, to detect artificial displacement fields caused by the self-heating of the CT scanner. Then, the artificial displacement fields can be fitted using linear polynomials. After that, the artificial displacements can be subtracted from the directly measured ones to recover the desired deformation fields. Other methods using ball-like objects [, 26: #mstaa60adbib026,, 27: #mstaa60adbib027] or hole plates [, 28: #mstaa60adbib028] can also be employed to compensate the self-heating effect in CT scanners

The self-heating effect in a CT scanner introduces considerable artificial dilatational strains, which depend on scan durations (relying on spatial resolution, angular resolution and exposure time, etc.). For volumetric images acquired with longer scan durations, the systematic errors in DVC measurements tend to increase correspondingly. However, the ZNCC correlation coefficients associated with longer scan durations are larger than those due to fast scans, which indicates higher image quality with less random noise can be obtained for longer scan durations. For this reason, it is considered that longer scans are preferable provided that the induced artificial strains can be well corrected

For the CT scanner used in this work, more than 3 h is needed to achieve the thermal equilibrium. The corresponding maximum artificial strains exceed 400 microstrain. Thus, to achieve high-accuracy DVC measurements for experimental mechanics applications, the influence of these artificial strains should be carefully considered

Three solutions that can be used to minimize the artificial strain due to the self-heating effect are suggested. The effectiveness of the correction method based on the experimentally characterized artificial strain-time curve are demonstrated by real compression tests performed on 3D printed samples
